issue.title: vrc rough terrain made up of steps

content.raw: added images of steps in rough terrain for reference ... image 3 is one of the large hills in the background to illustrate the stair effect more clearly.
content.html: added images of steps in rough terrain for reference ... image 3 is one of the large hills in the background to illustrate the stair effect more clearly.

issue.title: vrc rough terrain made up of steps

content.raw:
Keep in mind it is very helpful to have a soft foot to handle rounded terrain. The current rigid planar foot would have a single point of contact and no yaw resistance on a round object with convex curvature in all directions.
So we need planar segments. They just don't have to be exactly flat.

To fix the heightmap, you could also use a .png file for the heightmap with more depth. Looks like you can have up to 16bits per "color" and 64bits per "pixel". Greyscale with 16 bits per pixel probably is the easiest to switch to.
content.html:
Keep in mind it is very helpful to have a soft foot to handle rounded terrain. The current rigid planar foot would have a single point of contact and no yaw resistance on a round object with convex curvature in all directions. So we need planar segments. They just don't have to be exactly flat.

To fix the heightmap, you could also use a .png file for the heightmap with more depth. Looks like you can have up to 16bits per "color" and 64bits per "pixel". Greyscale with 16 bits per pixel probably is the easiest to switch to.

issue.title: vrc rough terrain made up of steps

content.raw:
I agree - the goal wouldn't be to create a completely smooth (or rough), high resolution terrain, but to have more variance than just multiple planes with (0,0,1) surface normal as even the Mobility qual world requires the robot to walk slopes and not just steps. 

I think the best solution for VRC might be to to create a very high resolution terrain via heightmap and then downsample it into a triangle mesh (either uniform or via more complex polygon reduction algorithms as offered by cad software, but right now I'm leaning towards thinking that uniform sampling might give better results for our purpose).
This would allow for a process that makes it relatively easy to generate terrain that should be usable for walking without compliant shoes if the sampling distance is chosen large enough, while removing 3 or more bugs that come along with using the current Gazebo heightmaps (increased parallax, poor lidar performance, limited resolution, ...).
content.html:
I agree - the goal wouldn't be to create a completely smooth (or rough), high resolution terrain, but to have more variance than just multiple planes with (0,0,1) surface normal as even the Mobility qual world requires the robot to walk slopes and not just steps.

I think the best solution for VRC might be to to create a very high resolution terrain via heightmap and then downsample it into a triangle mesh (either uniform or via more complex polygon reduction algorithms as offered by cad software, but right now I'm leaning towards thinking that uniform sampling might give better results for our purpose). This would allow for a process that makes it relatively easy to generate terrain that should be usable for walking without compliant shoes if the sampling distance is chosen large enough, while removing 3 or more bugs that come along with using the current Gazebo heightmaps (increased parallax, poor lidar performance, limited resolution, ...).
